story:
Dthulhu!

Note: Since the end of the original campaign Dthulhu is now shipping only when a certain amount of orders are received, (taking from at least 4 to 6 weeks.) This is making for somewhat irregular delivery times. If you wish to know when orders are expected to ship you can send us a private message. ;) 

Additionally we have only a limited number of the original Dthulhu sculpts left. All other perks are sold out, (including all glow sculpts.)

 

Catch Dthulhu on:

TOMOPOP

PLASTIC AND PLUSH

THE TOY CHRONICLE

THE TOY VIKING

TENACIOUSTOYS

URBAN VINYL DAILY

BELL OF LOST SOULS

BERLIN LOGS

JOE MONSTER

BLOG DE BRINQUEDO

TOYS R EVIL

 

Dthulhu: The Vinyl Sculpture

Dthulhu the vinyl sculpture


Dthulhu will be medical and food grade, PVC, Phthalate, and BPA free recycled vinyl. Just like a regular rubber duck, (many quality rubber ducks are vinyl) Dthulhu can play in the tub and will also squeak when squeezed! What could be more fun than your very own Old One in the tub!
 

Dthulhu started as a concept painting and was then sculpted digitally in a computer

 

Dthulhu Packaging

Dthulhu will come in a full color box which will have the theme of the poster as well as a window so you can see The Old One sleeping behind the great doors in front of the palace in R'lyeh.

Dthulhu's madness packaging

Across the front of the box is the chant of the cult members and on the right hand side is the translation:

"Ph'nglui mglw'nafh Dthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn"

"In his house at R'lyeh dead Dthulhu waits dreaming

On the opposite side is an original poem dedicated to Dthulhu and written by my wife Sasha Prince,

From the deep crawl eyes that creep with green and hidden terror.

They beckon those who crave its throes of sadness and despair.

They spread their slime and turn to grime the believers who in error

lose their hope and for proof grope after a deathly prayer.

 

The Dthulhu Limited Edition Poster (No longer available)

NOTE: As a bonus I will sign all of the art posters!

In addition to the sculpture there is a limited edition poster to accompany Dthulhu in its new home. I am a huge fan of poster artists and when I first arrived in Austin the poster art scene blew my mind. I discovered incredible illustrators and artists in Texas who worked in the poster and rock world and who made incredible art. This poster is a homage to them. Also, aside from comics, the poster classics of the 60's and 70's have influenced my art, so to invoke the spirit of these times, I listened to lots of 70’s music (lots of Sabbath) while designing the poster.

The Dthulhu Limited Edition Poster

The Limited Edition Poster is based on the original concept for the duck which I made the morning after I had the dream. It is always hard to remember exactly what we see in dreams and what we see doesn’t always mean it will translate to design. As any artist would, I tried to bridge the gap and the result was my first concept.

Original concept painting

I also wanted to make sure it paid homage to the original story. As an Illustrator I have always thought about how to visually handle the non-Euclidean geometry of R'lyeh. It was fun to illustrate the city and its giant doors. If you look closely at the bottom you will see the Norwegian sailor, Gustaf Johansen.

The poster is 18x24 inches and will be printed on high quality 100 lbs gloss paper suitable for framing. 

 

Dthulhu Paper sculpture (No longer available)

Yes it’s true! You can download and build your very own paper-craft Dthulhu, (non-Euclidean geometry not included.) Children will love to build the Lord of Madness! Use Dthulhu to spice up the office, a party; anyplace becomes insanely fun once the Great Old One is present. Transform any occasion into madness!

Paper Downloadable Dthulhu

The extra-large paper version of Dthulhu can be printed with any home printer. It comes as a PDF and can be re-printed for years to come.

Paper Downloadable Dthulhu printed

 

Dthulhu Downloadable Poster & Desktop Image (No longer available)

 

The Dthulhu downloadable poster and desktop screen saver is a 3D rendered image of Dthulhu in an underwater bathroom in R’lyeh. It is the image of Dthulhu I created in 3D and will look great on the wall. Print it and hang it in your favorite bathroom or splash it on your desktop displaying your madness for The Old One.

Dthulhu Downloadable 3D mini-Poster & Desktop Image

 

Rewards Overview!

 

Glow Dthulhu (pictured below) is no longer available. 

 

Dthulhu Development

The development for Dthulhu started with the concept art and the main design work was done in 3D. Since the product is an exact print of the 3D model I wanted to get the size and scale exactly right. I made multiple prototypes with a printing software that allows the building of them in paper (as seen in the video and below).

Computer and paper prototypes

This was the impetus for the downloadable paper duck. I am very happy with the final dimensions that I have chosen for Dthulhu.

 

Risks and challenges

The challenge for this project, besides completing it, was to keep it simple. With the help of a good friend in the toy industry and others who have contributed their opinions, I believe I have accomplished this goal. I also enlisted the help of my wife who will be helping me manage fulfillment. The real risk is, of course, that it won’t succeed. But when I look at this project I am amazed because I now live in an age when I can create something and bring into existence and directly reach a potential market. Just ten years ago this would not have been possible and I am grateful that Indiegogo has given me this opportunity.

I have art directed numerous video game projects as well as worked as a creative director and a project director. Additionally, I have run my own digital freelance studio creating corporate identities, rock posters, media promos and more. Before my entry into the video game industry I ran my own screen printing company in Austin, Texas, creating original clothing as well as custom apparel for clients. This is an exciting new venture for me.

 

FAQ:

Will Dthulhu make a noise?

Yes! When squeezed Dthulhu will utter the “sound of a thousand souls that are squeezed together.” (Thank you, Gerard van den Akker!) Actually, Dthulhu will squeak when squeezed.

Why are Dthulhu’s eyes flat on the bottom?

In the original dream I distinctly remembered the eyes and their shape. I wanted them to remain true to the inspiration.

Will Dthulhu be like a rubber duck? Can I take it in the tub?

Yes! Many rubber ducks are vinyl. Dthulhu will a high quality rubber duck.

How different will the color be between the glow in the dark and the regular Dthulhu?

The glow in the dark, by nature of its glow properties, will be much lighter, so the glow-in-the dark Dthulhu will be very, very light, as opposed to the deeper green of the non-glow Dthulhu. Whitish green, like most any Glow in the Dark object.

Why did the perks change?

Once we placed the initial order for the duck there were a finite amount. The perks reflect what is now available.

Why are Dthulhu's tentacles round and erect, why don't they droop down?

Dthulhu's tentacles form the basic shape of a ducks bill. During the design Phase I tried some droopy tapered tentacles but they  greatly subtracted from Dthulhu's duck shape. Dthulhu's novelty is in being a rubber duck and with doopy/tapered tentacles much of that character along with the "cute factor" was lost. 

But not to worry Dthulhu is young. They will droop down with time ...Aeons.

Will Dthulhu haunt my dreams and drive me to madness?

"Ph'nglui mglw'nafh Dthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn"

story:
Why This Matters

Your donation helps to support independent artists in an ongoing protest against the racist policies of the current administration of the United States. Resist through art.

What We Need 

We need to buy materials for our SFAI performance. (Our original piece on Inauguration Day was out of pocket--eeeks!)

Here's what we need:

  • Materials for constructing and painting cubes
  • Transportation
  • Performers
  • Video documentation & live broadcast

Hope to see you at the San Francisco Art Institute

We would love to see you at the San Francisco Art Institute for our performance, "This Is How It Happens," which is part of the ongoing protest.

March 17th at 4:00PM 

San Francisco Art Institute #Flagexchange 

Perks

Screen print prototype---will be in 3+ groovy colors

story:
Hi, my name is Alexandre, my wife's name is Maureen, we have two small children, Thomas and Matanya. A third child is on the way. We arrived at an important crossroad in our life. After seven years living in a community in the Galilee, a place we truly love, where we are happy to see our children growing, where we love our neighbors and where we feel at home, we are asked now to build our house. Because the jobs we have been doing those last years, I'm working with special need adults and my wife is accompanying old people in their last years of life, we haven't been able to save any money. The only way to achieve our goal it's you, the biggest number of "you" possible. Like in the tribes, when the whole village would gather to build a hut for a new family.

            The house would be in a natural landscape. I work a lot with wood. I build rooms, benches, beds, libraries. The house will be full of wood, facing the threes, not far from the horses of the kibutz. It would be a simple house, with a big restroom and kitchen  to receive friends and family. The bedrooms would be smaller. We would have a stove in the living room, to warm with logs in winter. It would be a good simple house with a lively garden. 

             Our families managed to bring 20,000 euros, but it's far than enough to make a loan, here in Israel. Because we are living in a kibutz, we are entitled for a 50 % loan of our construction money. We want the most modest house possible, that would be around 90 meter square, enough for the five of us to live in. We need all together a minimum of 150,000 euros to build the house. With this project we hope and dream to raise 60,000 euros. 

             It looks overwhelming , unbelievable , but it can happened. If we take it seriously, at heart, we will do it. There are no specific reasons to do it and they may be a millions of good ones. I put this project into the art section because I think this is social art. It's about creating a possibility where it seemed unlikely. It's made out of the dust of stars.

             We need support to spread this project, they may be many a helping hand and there is no way to know who it may interest.

             From all our heart, thank you and bless you.

story:
"If your actions inspire others to dream more, learn more, do more and become more, you are a leader." – John Quincy Adams

WHO AM I?

My name is Manu Barso. I was born in Argentina in the city of Neuquen, in the Patagonia region. At 17 years old, I enrolled in the University of Buenos Aires (UBA), studying Design of Image and Sound; with a group of students we create a space call 'El Subsuelo Audiovisual', it was a similar concept that i am presenting to you today; people gathering doing art, selling art, and offering any type of talents.  After school, I lived in Puerto Rico where I worked to coordinate numerous art events and assisted professional artists. I also worked in filmography as a producer and camera assistant.
I am an independent woman, a hard worker, and goal oriented. I am creative, organised and practical. I have had a variety of other jobs, everything from managing a successful clothing store, to cleaning houses. No matter the type of work, I conduct myself in a professional manner, and strive to get the most out of every experience that I have. 

LET'S DO THIS!

To make my dream of developing the art community in San Juan del Sur a reality, I need your help. Together we can create a forum for the practice and appreciation of art in SJDS, Nicaragua and change peoples lives by providing a creative outlet and community space for tourists and locals alike. The Art Warehouse will bring our town’s residents and visitors together, blurring the line between the two groups. This is also a way of create a world conscience and awareness about art in general, people can live out of art and there are possibilities for everyone in this life that is willing to take them and make the best out of each situation in life. 

The Warehouse seeks to unify the two social classes that coexist in SJDS. We hope to provide a unique opportunity for community growth, learning new languages, and the acceptance of cultural diversity. I have met many Nicaraguans who have been inspired by tourists in SJDS to travel the world and create friendly ties, also foreigners the same way around they learn and live from Experiences and get involve in the culture.  We want to offer professional support, a qualified person to teach art, receiving boys and girls in town who need and want to receive tools that would advance their lives.

 

FUNCTIONS OF THE BUSINESS: 

To make our mission sustainable, we will rely on multiple programs and their associated revenue streams. Each of these aspects of the business are outlined below.

ART GALLERY: 

There will be art displayed around the entire premises with its corresponding price tags and information about the piece and the artist. The personal working will be highly trained to sell art, and educated on each piece in the gallery. Sale online will be available for those who prefer it, facilitated by online payments and a 3rd party shipper. 

We expect that commission on art sales will be our greatest source of revenue. At times we will buy art directly from artists for display in the gallery until it is sold. The other approach will be with artist that are interested in displaying and selling more than one piece.

 

WORKSHOPS: 

We will offer spaces to rent out to teachers to give classes of any type of art. We will supply the facilities and material if needed. We will work like a team to organise and promote these courses. 

The idea is that it is a permanent work station where people educate them self and explore around the place with total freedom. 

SPECIAL EVENTS: 

Once every 2 month or less we will put on Special Gallery Nights to promote sales and culture, offer an unforgettable experience, and help expose our mission to a larger audience. We will also bring new things into town, like Theater Shows and Movie Nights. 

This is one of the most beneficial areas because it will generate immediate return without taking on additional inventory. For these events, we will bring in 3rd party food and drink vendors and collect a commission for their sales. In addition to the revenue generated from food and drink sales, we expect art sales revenue to be elevated during these events. This concept have proven its viability with special Art Nights hosted at the Cerveceria SJDS, this event created by Maria Delgado* and Manu Barso  was a total success; the art sales increase a 70% every time, during each of the three events, average food and drink sales increased by more than 100% too.

I have also created an event series called White Canvas where invited guests pay for the opportunity to create art in a comunal setting (www.facebook.com/whitecanvasevent/).

*Maria Delgado: Nicaraguan Illustrator, Collage artist & Publicist. Maria is a young inspirational artist who want to embrace and bring art to peoples life, her preferred mediums are illustration and both analogue and digital collages. You can see her work in Instagram and contact her for freelance jobs.   https://www.instagram.com/mariadelgado33/

STUDIO SPACE: 

We will offer traveling artists or others who don’t have their own studio space a place to work. We will rent the spaces for an affordable cost. These studio rentals will only be utilised pending availability and the class schedule. 

Pricing for studio space rental will be based on memberships v. one- time rentals. We will offer discounts to people purchasing packages for regular use as well as a higher single-use rate for travellers or others not interested in committing to our packages.

COFFEE BAR: 

We will have a fully functioning coffee bar that will generate revenue by selling coffee and pastries to customers. This will also support the other arms of the business by giving people what they need to stay in the Warehouse for an extended period of time. It will also help drive traffic by attracting customers who are not solely interested in art. We will also sell coffee in bags and other local artisanal foods such as honey and craft beer. 

 

ART SUPPLY SHOP: 

In addition to offering people a venue to practice their art or lessons, we will sell art supplies to accommodate customers needs. This area is key as customers will understand that the only other option to get art supplies is in Managua, 2 hours from San Juan. We will also create a system of rental equipment for items that are too bulky to carry on vacation, or too expensive, or used only periodically. This will not only give people what they need to use our studios, it will represent a complimentary source of revenue. 

Our supply store will have the best selection of art supplies in SJDS. We will stock a variety of different materials at different price points. This will ensure that we will sell supplies to both people practicing in our studios and outside (school children, artists who have their own studios, etc.). We will work to stock supplies in a cost effective manner and be sure that our retail prices reflect a healthy profit margin while also responding to demand.  Traveler art kits custom made will be our signature. Because everyone deserve to carry on arting ;p 

 

FUNDING:

To execute this project, I am raising up to $35,000. The table below outlines how the funds will be allocated if I meet my goal.

 

I believe that an investment of effort and effort into the development of art in San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua will go directly towards improving the quality of life of many people. 

 

A BIGER VISION FOR THE FUTURE 

My long term goal for The Warehouse is to help enhance and develop the imagination and potential of the people of Nicaragua. By coming in every time and do something; grave a book and read, take a pen and draw, take a sit and be silence. To obtain knowledge of your actions on a daily basis.

Having establish a general intelligent system of people coming in and out of the instalations, creating and inventing new ways of living; interacting and making new connections, gathering and enjoying life as art well knows. 

Give it back:The circle of life- (Recycling project) Recycling is one of the best opportunities to create and reinvent from scratch.
We will have a program that help to create furniture and useful stuff for the community made out of recycling materials. Starting with basic techniques and small creations, we will develop our recycling program over time as we perfect techniques and invest in specialized equipment.
story_txt: "If your actions inspire others to dream more, learn more, do more and become more, you are a leader." – John Quincy AdamsWHO AM I?My name is Manu Barso. I was born in Argentina in the city of Neuquen, in the Patagonia region. At 17 years old, I enrolled in the University of Buenos Aires (UBA), studying Design of Image and Sound; with a group of students we create a space call 'El Subsuelo Audiovisual', it was a similar concept that i am presenting to you today; people gathering doing art, selling art, and offering any type of talents.  After school, I lived in Puerto Rico where I worked to coordinate numerous art events and assisted professional artists. I also worked in filmography as a producer and camera assistant.I am an independent woman, a hard worker, and goal oriented. I am creative, organised and practical. I have had a variety of other jobs, everything from managing a successful clothing store, to cleaning houses. No matter the type of work, I conduct myself in a professional manner, and strive to get the most out of every experience that I have. LET'S DO THIS!To make my dream of developing the art community in San Juan del Sur a reality, I need your help. story:
Phil Sylvester and Family / Berlin Exhibitions


Hi, I'm Phil Sylvester, artist and guitar maker. This year, I have been invited to participate in the Holy Grail Guitar Show, in Berlin, the best guitar show in the world. Only 115 luthiers are invited worldwide each year. I've also set up an opportunity to show my recent drawings in Berlin while we are there. This trip will be very expensive, actually far beyond my family's means, but it is an opportunity we would be foolish to turn down. We are asking friends and supporters to contribute so that we can pull this trip off. We are also doing multiple fundraisers selling drawings and paintings at The Drawing Studio, where my wife Joan and I make our work.

Joan and my son Eoin will be traveling with me as I need helpers both to carry the guitars we will be taking and to help man the booth at the show. Also, a trip like this is important from a health standpoint for Eoin, who's world can become extremely small because of his autism. Truth in advertising, we are adding ten days in Paris as long as we're there because Eoin is intensely interested in the history of Paris.

The Holy Grail Guitar Show will expose my guitars to the world's most serious guitar collectors. Such exposure is particularly important for independent guitar makers because collectors really can't evaluate guitars without having the guitars in their hands. Even more so for my work, as it is often thought that my guitars are designed for visual impact alone. One has to play my guitars to realize that my first concerns are how they sound and how they play. One has to play my guitars to realize that I am striving to make guitars that are among the best in the world.

Because this show will put my guitars into the hands of collectors and players from all over the world, it has the potential to really change the amount of work I can sell, as well as radically change the long term trajectory of my career. The show gets exceptional coverage in all the important guitar publications. Just that coverage alone will create advertising for my work that I couldn't match any other way. 

Finally, the drawings I make nowadays are, as you may know, "difficult". They are impossible to develop a market for in Portland. Berlin, however, is an entirely different story. Berlin is, most likely, the best conceivable place for my drawings to build a following, you know, its being so decadent and all. I would love to begin selling enough of my drawings to justify my committing more and more time to that part of my work.

So, the trip is about much more than just going to the show. Your contributions have the potential to change the future for my art and my family. I doubt that we will reach anywhere near our fundraising goal, but on the off chance that we wildly exceed it, extra moneys will go to our massive debt as a studio and to future reckless indulgences like health insurance and studio improvements. 

Thanks so much for your support.

Phil Sylvester, Pheo Guitars

story:
Pari is a new artist-run initiative in Parramatta. We are for art that tells stories that need to be told, sheds new light on old thinking, or tackles new ideas altogether. We are for getting you to Parra, or making it so that you don’t have to leave here to come together over new, challenging, boundary-pushing art. We are for bringing art and ideas to Western Sydney audiences, and bringing audiences from elsewhere to experience art in the crane-hogging, uber-developing, beautifully contradictory and diverse place we call Parramatta, in the geographical centre of Sydney’s urban sprawl, in the heart of unceded Darug territory. 

We will facilitate the space, but what Pari is will be defined by the people who show here, the people who come and look and listen, the conversations that happen, the things that get said and thought and reconsidered.

The first few shows at Pari will be curated in-house, after which time exhibitions will be programmed from open call outs. Pari will pay artist fees for every exhibition and public program, with support from the NSW Government through Create NSW. 

What we do not have funding for, however, is our fit out. This is where you come in. We have secured a lease on a commercial property in the Parramatta CBD, on the retail ground floor of a council car park on Hunter Street, a short walk from Parramatta train and bus station. It is currently fitted out as a cafe, and we need your help to transform it into a contemporary art space. 

We have come up with a plan for the fit out that will be functional and striking while avoiding being overly costly or resource-heavy. Our fundraising target will allow us to complete the following works:

  • Removal or covering of existing café fittings, including boarding up grease traps
  • Constructing and painting gallery walls (studs, mdf, gyprock, plastering)
  • Purchasing materials to create a flexible internal hanging system

Our conservative estimate of costs are:

  • $6,500 Raw Materials (e.g. timber, gyprock, MDF, paint, steel, scaffolding)
  • $1,500 Contractors (e.g. electrical & plumbing)
  • $1,500 Furniture (e.g. shelving, meeting tables, folding chairs)
  • $500 Contingency

Any funding we receive over the target amount will go towards purchasing items from our gallery wish list:

  • Media players
  • Speakers
  • A projector
  • 2 x matching TV screens
  • Cabling
  • A platform ladder on wheels

story:
Update:

We want to thank all of you for your generosity and getting us past our initial goal; we are both thrilled and humbled by your support. Your contributions enable us to meet our baseline needs of securing the gallery and cinema spaces, and providing free access to all events. 

But we’re not done yet! We are setting a stretch goal, first at a $7,000 mark - these funds will go towards  covering the additional gallery installation costs, printing of individual projects, and costs to make the events more accessible and enjoyable for our audiences!

We are a group of 20 passionate and emerging filmmakers and photographers working to further our skills by completing a Master of Fine Arts, Documentary Media Program at Ryerson University. The DocNow Festival is the culmination of two years of hard work and an integral step in completing our degree: publicly showing our work.  We have a lot to say and look forward to the opportunity to say it. 

This year is something special: the DocNow Festival celebrates its 10th anniversary.  Putting on a festival is a lot of work and we have a lot to pay for.  The good news is we have raised half the funds needed to put on the festival.  Your sponsorship will help us close the deal and continue the tradition of excellence and free access to all events.  The festival will be shown in 4 film screenings and 10 gallery installations throughout the month of June 2018. 

 

The largest portion of our budget pays for film theatres and galleries to show the work.  But there are other expenses, like speaker fees, film processing, website,  printing,  promotional costs, festival events,  administration, etc.  Our priority is to pay for the theatres and galleries.   If we don't get all the funds needed, we will have to cut back on our schedule, and cut the other costs impacting the quality of the festival, production and access.

But this campaign is BOTH give and take. We have perks that kick in at different contribution levels, such as priority seating at screening events, giveaways, artworks, and the ultimate expression of support: "the whole shebang".

 

And there are even more ways you can help DocNow:

  • Share our website on your social media! (http://www.docnow.ca/) 
  • Go to DocNow.ca and sign up for updates!
  • Follow us on Instagram, Twitter and Like Us on Facebook!
  • Join us in June 2018 at any of our events!

story:
Controlling_Connectivity: Background

"With the opportunity for connectivity and limitless access to information, comes the obligation to be increasingly available to receive and transmit; to be perpetually connected. The consequent erosion of true leisure time, the blurring of the traditional professional/ personal, public/ private dichotomies, and an information overload are creating hitherto unknown levels of psychological pressure.


Controlling_Connectivity was an art project by artist Gretta Louw, which used the pervasiveness of internet-based social networking, and the obligation as well as the opportunity for constant connection with these platforms as a paradigm for a severe and systematic disruption of normal, socially accepted patterns of life and interpersonal interaction during a self-documented performance. Taking to its natural extreme the notion that new technologies are increasingly dictating our social interaction, professional life, and have a far reaching effect on many other aspects of daily life, Louw completed a durational performance as she lived in the gallery space in complete isolation except for contact through various social networking sites on the internet.


For 10 days the artist was available 24 hr/day for discussions, emails, comments, or interviews - of both private and professional nature - for any internet user wishing to take part in the project. All necessary supplies were stored within the gallery and the windows were blacked out to ensure that the environment was not normalised by natural light or the social rhythms outside, but defined purely by the internet connection to external participants."
(Text from Art Laboratory Berlin)

Following the conclusion of the performance a solo exhibition in the gallery space, Art Laboratory Berlin, curated by Christian de Lutz and Regine Rapp, was installed. The new video, sound, and installation works are based on documentation from the performance and examine issues around societal and cultural change as a result of the development of internet technologies, as well as the increasing psychological pressure on individuals that result.

The Publication

The book brings together documentation of the project - images from the performance and the exhibition, as well as text contributions from participants and discussions with the artist - in a comprehensive analogue overview. The project is contextualised by critical essays from the curators Christian de Lutz and Regine Rapp, who examine the art historical context and contribution. Interviews with the artist provide insight into the internal, mental changes brought about by the project, as well as highlighting some of the most memorable experiences. Theoretical texts from art and media theorists, such as Dr Leon Tan, expand the relevance of the book as a significant assessment of where we as a society stand in relation to the internet and how these radical technological advancements are silently shaping us.

Printed on high quality semi gloss paper (170 gsm), the limited edition book comes with a DVD video piece comprising edited screen recordings from conversations, interviews, and discussions recorded during the performance. Addressing topics from Performance Art to internet addiction, the potential of technological advancement to alter our perception of time and reality, and the ways in which the internet affects communication, relationships, and thereby even perhaps identity itself, the video piece is a fascinating record of current thoughts around the internet and its psychological, cultural, and sociological consequences.

Funding Needed

Funding is required primarily for the material and printing costs to produce the book and DVD. However it is also important to me to offer some remuneration to the writers for their efforts and skill.

I would greatly appreciate your support to get this record of the Controlling_Connectivity project published. I believe this is not only an important conclusion to this project, in order to have a comprehensive, analogue record of a predominantly digital project, but also that it is a significant document of many different perspectives and theories around the dramatic impact of internet technologies - something that is at the very crux of the Information Age zeitgeist.

Pre-order the limited edition, signed and numbered artist's book incl. DVD and shipping with a donation of US$30. Or, even better, become a sponsor of the publication, or order yourself a high quality digital print from the project.

Further Details

For more information about the project and to see some existing documentation, visit: http://controllingconnectivity.tumblr.com/
More video documentation from the performance can be viewed here: http://vimeo.com/user7570190

If you have any further questions about the project, the book, or this fundraising effort, please don't hesitate to contact me.

The performance and exhibition part of the project was made possible by the generous support of the Karin Abt-Straubinger Stiftung.

                used the pervasiveness of internet-based social networking, and 
                the obligation as well as the opportunity for constant connection 
                with these platforms as a paradigm for a severe and systematic 
                disruption of normal, socially accepted patterns of life and interpersonal 
                interaction during a self-documented performance. Taking to its 
                natural extreme the notion that new technologies are increasingly 
                dictating our social interaction, professional life, and have 
                a far reaching effect on many other aspects of daily life, Louw completed a durational performance as she lived in the gallery space in complete 
                isolation except for contact through various social networking 
                sites on the internet. 
For 
                10 days the artist was available 24 hr/day for discussions, emails, 
                comments, or interviews - of both private and professional nature 
                - for any internet user wishing to take part in the project. All 
                necessary supplies were stored within the gallery and the windows 
                were blacked out to ensure that the environment was not normalised 
                by natural light or the social rhythms outside, but defined purely 
                by the internet connection to external participants."(Text from Art Laboratory Berlin)Following the conclusion of the performance a solo exhibition in the gallery space, Art Laboratory Berlin, curated by Christian de Lutz and Regine Rapp, was installed. The new video, sound, and installation works are based on documentation from the performance and examine issues around societal and cultural change as a result of the development of internet technologies, as well as the increasing psychological pressure on individuals that result.The PublicationThe book brings together documentation of the project - images from the performance and the exhibition, as well as text contributions from participants and discussions with the artist - in a comprehensive analogue overview. The project is contextualised by critical essays from the curators Christian de Lutz and Regine Rapp, who examine the art historical context and contribution. Interviews with the artist provide insight into the internal, mental changes brought about by the project, as well as highlighting some of the most memorable experiences. Theoretical texts from art and media theorists, such as Dr Leon Tan, expand the relevance of the book as a significant assessment of where we as a society stand in relation to the internet and how these radical technological advancements are silently shaping us.Printed on high quality semi gloss paper (170 gsm), the limited edition book comes with a DVD video piece comprising edited screen recordings from conversations, interviews, and discussions recorded during the performance. Addressing topics from Performance Art to internet addiction, the potential of technological advancement to alter our perception of time and reality, and the ways in which the internet affects communication, relationships, and thereby even perhaps identity itself, the video piece is a fascinating record of current thoughts around the internet and its psychological, cultural, and sociological consequences.Funding NeededFunding is required primarily for the material and printing costs to produce the book and DVD. However it is also important to me to offer some remuneration to the writers for their efforts and skill.I would greatly appreciate your support to get this record of the Controlling_Connectivity project published. I believe this is not only an important conclusion to this project, in order to have a comprehensive, analogue record of a predominantly digital project, but also that it is a significant document of many different perspectives and theories around the dramatic impact of internet technologies - something that is at the very crux of the Information Age zeitgeist.Pre-order the limited edition, signed and numbered artist's book incl. DVD and shipping with a donation of US$30. Or, even better, become a sponsor of the publication, or order yourself a high quality digital print from the project.Further DetailsFor more information about the project and to see some existing documentation, visit: http://controllingconnectivity.tumblr.com/More video documentation from the performance can be viewed here: http://vimeo.com/user7570190If you have any further questions about the project, the book, or this fundraising effort, please don't hesitate to contact me.The performance and exhibition part of the project was made possible by the generous support of the Karin Abt-Straubinger Stiftung.

story:
Cover illustration by Harry Campbell

SPECIAL TRIBUTE ISSUE

DEDICATED TO NEWTOWN, CT

THE NEWTOWNER  is a one-of-a-kind arts and literary magazine that showcases the work of emerging and established literary, visual, and performing artists from our local area and across the nation.

THE NEWTOWNER derives its name from Newtown, CT where we are based and from its residents who make this town so special.

Our mission is to celebrate creative community and the life-affirming power of literature and the arts.

In light of the events of 12/14/12, this mission has never been more relevant and important.

Our upcoming issue, due for release in July 2013, will be a special tribute issue offered as a healing gift to the town of Newtown. By its very nature it will be a publication of historic significance.

Our aims for this issue are to:

  • Celebrate the people, beauty, culture, and community spirit of Newtown, CT
  • Remember those we love and lost
  • Recognize and give artistic expression to the grief we have experienced
  • Highlight the role of the arts in healing and the arts’ ability to nurture our humanity
  • Focus on our love, faith, and hope for the future

Featuring contributions from:

  • Nationally acclaimed authors and illustrators such as  Wally Lamb, Lois Lowry, Katherine Paterson, and Steven Kellogg
  • Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Yusef Komunyakaa
  • Sesame Street’s Alan Muraoka 
  • National leaders such as Senators Richard Blumenthal and Chris Murphy
  • Newtown’s First Selectwoman Pat Llodra
  • Newtown faith leaders such as Rabbi Shaul Praver
  • Newtown educators such as Newtown High School Principal Chip Dumais and Reed Intermediate teacher Gael Lynch
  • Newtown High School students
  • Sandy Hook Elementary School parents David Wheeler and Sophfronia Scott
  • Sandy Hook Elementary School staff member Cindy Carlson
  • Sandy Hook Elementary School student artists Chase Kowalski, Jessica Rekos, and Avielle Richman

Call for sponsorship: Our hearts' desire is to provide complimentary copies to, if not every Newtown household, at least every Sandy Hook Elementary School family. We are looking for individual and corporate sponsor funding to be able to achieve this goal. Please contact editor@thenewtownermagazine.com to express your interest.

Call for volunteers: The Newtowner  is seeking volunteers and interns that would be interested in helping to produce this special tribute issue. Volunteer opportunities are available in the areas of writing, editing, public relations, publicity, fundraising, photography, illustration, design, and distribution. Please contact editor@thenewtownermagazine.com to express your interest.

Did you know that: 

  • Over the last two years we have published six acclaimed issues.
  • We are one of very few arts and literary magazines that operates as a grass roots, all-volunteer movement in a local community, and that is not funded by a university or college.
  • We are the only arts and literary journal we know of aimed at a general readership that regularly publishes the creative work of young writers and artists. We publish the work of elementary, middle-school, and high-school students in a dedicated section called "Youth Expressions."
  • Not only do we publish the work of young writers and artists, we mentor youth editors who select and edit the works published in the Youth Expressions section.
  • We work with and publish the creative work of Garner Correctional Institution inmates. We are the only arts and literary journal we know of that is doing this on a regular basis. This work is showcased in its own dedicated section called "From the Inside Out."
  • In the digital age, The Newtowner is an ode to print as an art form. It is a perfect bound, full-color art magazine printed on 100# weight silk-textured paper with exceptional graphic design. 
 

More than a magazine, THE NEWTOWNER is a community

More than a magazine, The Newtowner  is a community of readers, writers, editors, artists, and art lovers, who together support the arts and each other. 

The Newtowner' s community outreach has included:

  • Community poetry and prose readings 
  • Launch issue celebrations that have been open to the public
  • Creation of the Inaugural Newtowner Open Poetry Award
  • Creation of The Newtowner/Newtown High School Poetry Award
  • Mentoring of high school and middle school youth editors 
  • Musical and dramatic performances
  • Dance workshops 
  • Panel discussions
  • Newtown Arts Festival support and involvement
  • Local library events
  • Attendance at readings and performances by inmates at Garner Correctional Institution by the staff of The Newtowner
  • Venetian-inspired Masked Ball to celebrate our first anniversary

Inaugural Issue Launch, December 2010

Praise for THE NEWTOWNER

"I am a lucky guy to have been profiled in such a gorgeous and arts-friendly magazine. The Newtowner has it all: compelling writing, great photography, and an attractive layout that can proudly stand beside the New York 'slicks.' Each issue is a pleasure to read."     -- Wally Lamb, best-selling novelist                                                                                                                    

For those engaged in the world of arts and literature, having a publication like this available to your community is something of a dream come true."    --Mark Danowsky, NewPages.com

"The most complimentary thing I can say about The Newtowner is that it is real. It bleeds and sweats and has soul. Thank you."   --Vincent, Garner CI

“Your publication is delicious . . . a deep dish apple pie of a magazine.”  -- Ethel-Anne Roome

The team behind THE NEWTOWNER

The Newtowner is run by a highly talented, all-volunteer staff with exceptional background and experience in literature and the arts. 

Our team includes Editor in Chief Georgia Monaghan, Associate Editor Aimee Pokwatka, Fiction Editor Wendy Wipprecht, Poetry Editor Lisa Schwartz, Creative Nonfiction Editor Brenda McKinley, Assistant Poetry Editor Nancy Bocian, Acquisitions Editor Sue Kassirer, Proofreader Jennifer Jackson, Columnist Julie Stern, Art Designers Tracy Hubbard and Tarol Samuelson, Photographer Darren Wagner, Illustrator Luke Kennedy, Special Projects and Promotions Coordinator Sheryl Fatse, Public Relations Coordinator Maka  Bakhbava, Youth Staff Nikki Barnhart, Grace McKinley, Caroline McArdle, Lucien Formichella, and Sarah Clements.

Please visit the About Us page on The Newtowner magazine website:www.thenewtownermagazine.com to read the bios of our exceptionally talented and experienced staff.

The Founding Editorial Team

Thank you in advance for whatever help you can offer in creating this healing gift for Newtown.

Warm regards,

Georgia Monaghan, Editor in Chief

on behalf on the team behind

THE NEWTOWNER

An Arts and Literary Magazine

203 304 1239

editor@thenewtownermagazine.com

www.thenewtownermagazine.com

story:
What We Need & What You Get

With Turnstyle Studio, I hope to bring the experience of Glass Blowing to Toronto.  I've been working in glass for the past 8 years and running my company; Balance Glassworks for the past 5.  My love of the material continues to grow.  Unfortunately, the overhead cost of running a glass studio can be prohibitively expensive.  Canada's small but vibrant and dedicated community of glass artists deserve a place to work that won't break the bank.  The only way to do this is to nurture that community and allow it to grow!  Through a graduated series of workshops, I hope to mold absolute beginners into self-sufficient glass artists in their own time and at their own pace.  Pulling from a larger pool of renters, the studio will develop a "drop-in" structure free of contracts and large monetary commitments.  Over $20 000 worth of equipment including a glass furnace with 200 lb. capacity has already been purchased and is currently in storage (Please inquire if you have questions about this equipment and you'll be sent a full list).   I know the interest is there, the missing piece is the facility.

The Impact

With each donation Turnstyle Glass Studio comes that much closer to becoming a reality.  The posted goal is meant to cover rent and utilities in the first year of operation.  High-level donors will receive placement in beginner level classes or studio time depending on their degree of training.  Every dollar helps and perks include items from the Balance Glassworks catalogue!  With your help and a bit of luck, the studio will be up and running for 2014 and become a resource for professional and amateur artists interested in working with and being educated in hot glass.

Other Ways You Can Help

Like I said, every loony helps, but even if you can't spare it, you can help the Canadian glass community simply by sharing this campaign with someone that you think might be interested.  Please come down for a visit next year and see what we're up to!

The Perks!

Hand-Sculpted Glass Wishbone


Balance T-Shirts

Dunlin Decanter

(Photo by Peter Stewart)

Hive Tumblers

(Photo by Peter Stewart)

Dunlin Gift Set

(Photo by Peter Stewart)

Beginner's Glass Workshop


Coporate Takeover

story:
I'm an artist living and working in the Atlanta area.  I've agreed to build 5-10 abstract sculptures to be installed at an upcoming arts and music festival - PhoenixFest. 

Amongst the ruins of a derelict motel site in the Lakewood community of Atlanta, Urban Sprout Farms has created a sanctuary for growing fresh produce. On November 15th, a group of champions for the Atlanta arts community are getting together to present a day of music, literature and art to raise awareness for this creative repurposing of land that was once laying to waste.

Entry to the festival is FREE with RSVP: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/phoenix-festival-tickets-13580805555

The sculpture series is called "Growth" and consists of building twisting conical shapes using insulation foam and plaster. "Growth" is an extension of a series I did several years ago, which I always envisioned in an outdoor space, surrounded by actual plant growth. 

This funding campaign is intended to cover the material costs to create approximately 7 sculptures of varying sizes (2-6 ft. tall). I'm estimating that the smaller sculptures will cost about $50 each to create and the larger ones will be about twice that. Materials include Great Stuff insulating foam, Plaster of Paris, and paint.  Additional materials for installation may include rebar and gravel or sandbags to secure the sculptures, if being installed in the pool/koi pond.  Final location is currently undetermined.
Any funds received will be applied to the cost of this project and any extra funding will just mean that I can make more or larger sculptures.

Any contribution of $50 or more will be eligible to receive a finished sculpture after PhoenixFest is over.  Local delivery/pick-up only. 

While I have started the process of building these sculptures, I quickly found that more materials would be required than I initially estimated.  Your help will be greatly appreciated!

This is 10 16oz. cans of Great Stuff. I started supplementing with packing peanuts to help stretch the volume produced.  The finished foam structures will be shaved down and shaped up a bit before plaster is applied to the exterior and finally painted.

Here are some examples of the ceramic version of this project from a few years ago:

story: I was accepted into the Listhús Artist Residency Program to further my research in the representation of aging.  My portraits of maturing women show the insecurities I have acquired with aging and losing my aesthetic marketability as I grow older.  This series centers on my mother and myself, but I would like to explore new subjects and materials in response to being engulfed in a new culture.  I’ve become more interested in the abstraction of the figure.  Focusing on sores, fluids, scabs, bruising, dark marks, and bulges, I’m representing the female portrait in a much more nonconventional way.  In Olafsjfordur, I will explore work with the aging figure in response to my new surroundings.  Unfamiliar textures, surfaces, and sensory experiences will aid the unknown feelings I have towards the ever-changing body.  With the access of and the building of new materials, my work will grow tremendously.  This experience will make my work more sculptural and lead me towards considering the idea as an installation. If you'd like to see other examples of my work or my Artist CV my website is www.sagannewham.com

story:
What we want to do

"If we knew what it was we were doing, it would not be called research, would it?" (Einstein, A)

We aim to create a legendary three day intensive open lab, at ISEA 2014 in Dubai, in the form of a living artwork/happening at the cutting edge of DIY biology practices, bioart, the body and digital technologies, taking the form of creative interactions between artists led by The Institute of Unnecessary Research (IUR) and The Egyptian Bioart Club.

This paradigm shifting open lab will facilitate collaborative working practices and cross cultural dialogue, with a focus on ethical debates and the role of the artist working within science settings in the West and the Arab World. The three day intensive collaborative workshop, will include hands on "do it together" microbiology and bioart with Anna Dumitriu and Heba El Aziz, participatory video mapping activities with Alex May and brainwave/lucid dreaming performance art with Luciana Haill as well as other activities and presentations. The workshop will be followed by a final public installation, exhibition and performance of the outcomes, with show and tell presentations on the third evening.

The open lab is aimed at all ages and backgrounds and welcomes drop in visitors. The Institute of Unnecessary Research (IUR) believes anyone can understand anything if it's explained properly, sometimes this means through artistic, participatory methods rather than top down knowledge dissemination. We will work on hands on projects, for example safely growing environmental bacteria to create bioartworks using a protocol developed between IUR Director Anna Dumitriu and scientists from Public Health England, using interactive technologies and video mapping using software by IUR Head of Projective Geometry Alex May, or working to control artworks with brainwave analysis with IUR Head of Augmented Consciousness Luciana Haill. Other IUR dept heads and Egyptian Bioart Club members will bring their own expertise. All the artists involved will discuss and demonstrate their areas of interest and expertise in an open way with visitors/participants. By bringing together artists from diverse backgrounds we will create a space for cross cultural dialogue, especially around issues such as medical ethics, data ethics, open source technologies, and Intellectual Property.

The Institute of Unnecessary Research presents a new paradigm in the way artists are engaging with the world through transdisciplinary practice and connective aesthetics. Bringing together art, science and philosophy by creating participatory audience experiences, performances and installations. Philosophy and ethics is always at the core of our work which unpacks the instrumentalization of science for commercial and political ends. http://www.unnecessaryresearch.org

The Egyptian Bioart Club stemmed from the British Council organised Egyptian Bioart Workshop which was led by Anna Dumitriu in Cairo in 2011, during the second Egyptian Revolution, and was founded by curator Yara Mekewei to create a platform for artists there to continue their bioart practice and share knowledge. Several members of the group have visited the UK to collaborate with the Institute of Unnecessary Research on artists' residencies and both groups are in regular discussion. http://www.facebook.com/groups/147828271984151/

What We Need & What You Get

We need some funds to make this happen! We can't afford to self fund it and we hope you agree that artists whose aims are for the benefit of society, for the furthering of human endeavour through unnecessary, curiosity driven research methods and widening participation in that dream, deserve support. The funds will go on flights, accomodation, food and materials and we'll help as many members of the IUR and Egyptian Bioart Club to come as we can raise funds for. We estimate costs for participants will be around £700 - £1000 each (depending on where they are travelling from) including airfare, conference fees, food and modest accomodation.

We are offering some exciting perks, plus you will get a warm fuzzy feeling of seeing what we do and knowing you were a part of it. Think of it like adopting a tiger cub in a zoo, but that tiger is an artist, their claws are digital technology and Petri dishes, and that zoo will be the most creative space in the world for those three days of the event.

The Impact

We want this even to be legendary! In the artworld, in the science world and as a beacon of Western/Arab collaboration.

All the artists involved have a great track record, check out our web links from the IUR website http://www.unnecessaryresearch.org . We work tirelessly on our unnecessary research projects and aim to reach out to as many people as possible.

With this event and our work, we aim to create a paradigm shift in the way knowledge and research is produced and disseminated. To make art a meta discipline that not only bridges the (imaginary) science, but brings together all disciplines and mixes and merges methods. It just might change the world!

You will be helping some of the most innovative artists in the world to create new work and synergies that without your support they would not be able to do.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Join the facebook group https://www.facebook.com/groups/119297011497093/

And don't forget to use the Indigogo tools to help us get support!
story_txt:
What we want to do
"If we knew what it was we were doing, it would not be called research, would it?" (Einstein, A)We aim to create a legendary three day intensive open lab, at ISEA 2014 in Dubai, in the form of a living artwork/happening at the cutting edge of DIY biology practices, bioart, the body and digital technologies, taking the form of creative interactions between artists led by The Institute of Unnecessary Research (IUR) and The Egyptian Bioart Club. This paradigm shifting open lab will facilitate collaborative working practices and cross cultural dialogue, with a focus on ethical debates and the role of the artist working within science settings in the West and the Arab World. The three day intensive collaborative workshop, will include hands on "do it together" microbiology and bioart with Anna Dumitriu and Heba El Aziz, participatory video mapping activities with Alex May and brainwave/lucid dreaming performance art with Luciana Haill as well as other activities and presentations. The workshop will be followed by a final public installation, exhibition and performance of the outcomes, with show and tell presentations on the third evening.The open lab is aimed at all ages and backgrounds and welcomes drop in visitors. The Institute of Unnecessary Research (IUR) believes anyone can understand anything if it's explained properly, sometimes this means through artistic, participatory methods rather than top down knowledge dissemination. We will work on hands on projects, for example safely growing environmental bacteria to create bioartworks using a protocol developed between IUR Director Anna Dumitriu and scientists from Public Health England, using interactive technologies and video mapping using software by IUR Head of Projective Geometry Alex May, or working to control artworks with brainwave analysis with IUR Head of Augmented Consciousness Luciana Haill. Other IUR dept heads and Egyptian Bioart Club members will bring their own expertise. All the artists involved will discuss and demonstrate their areas of interest and expertise in an open way with visitors/participants. By bringing together artists from diverse backgrounds we will create a space for cross cultural dialogue, especially around issues such as medical ethics, data ethics, open source technologies, and Intellectual Property.The Institute of Unnecessary Research presents a new paradigm in the way artists are engaging with the world through transdisciplinary practice and connective aesthetics. Bringing together art, science and philosophy by creating participatory audience experiences, performances and installations. Philosophy and ethics is always at the core of our work which unpacks the instrumentalization of science for commercial and political ends. http://www.unnecessaryresearch.org The Egyptian Bioart Club stemmed from the British Council organised Egyptian Bioart Workshop which was led by Anna Dumitriu in Cairo in 2011, during the second Egyptian Revolution, and was founded by curator Yara Mekewei to create a platform for artists there to continue their bioart practice and share knowledge. Several members of the group have visited the UK to collaborate with the Institute of Unnecessary Research on artists' residencies and both groups are in regular discussion. http://www.facebook.com/groups/147828271984151/What We Need & What You GetWe need some funds to make this happen! We can't afford to self fund it and we hope you agree that artists whose aims are for the benefit of society, for the furthering of human endeavour through unnecessary, curiosity driven research methods and widening participation in that dream, deserve support. The funds will go on flights, accomodation, food and materials and we'll help as many members of the IUR and Egyptian Bioart Club to come as we can raise funds for. We estimate costs for participants will be around £700 - £1000 each (depending on where they are travelling from) including airfare, conference fees, food and modest accomodation.We are offering some exciting perks, plus you will get a warm fuzzy feeling of seeing what we do and knowing you were a part of it. Think of it like adopting a tiger cub in a zoo, but that tiger is an artist, their claws are digital technology and Petri dishes, and that zoo will be the most creative space in the world for those three days of the event.The ImpactWe want this even to be legendary! In the artworld, in the science world and as a beacon of Western/Arab collaboration. All the artists involved have a great track record, check out our web links from the IUR website http://www.unnecessaryresearch.org . We work tirelessly on our unnecessary research projects and aim to reach out to as many people as possible. With this event and our work, we aim to create a paradigm shift in the way knowledge and research is produced and disseminated. To make art a meta discipline that not only bridges the (imaginary) science, but brings together all disciplines and mixes and merges methods. It just might change the world!You will be helping some of the most innovative artists in the world to create new work and synergies that without your support they would not be able to do.Other Ways You Can HelpSpread the word! Join the facebook group https://www.facebook.com/groups/119297011497093/And don't forget to use the Indigogo tools to help us get support!

story:
In February 2015 the Center for Digital Arts will present an exhibition of my sound-art work, curated by Liora Belford.

Most of you know my work as a composer and for using performance art practices in musical pieces. Since my first Gallery show at the Diapason Gallery in New York (curated by Michael J Schumacher in 2004) I've also been creating sound objects   that were shown in different exhibitions. This exhibition is the first time where I will be able to present these works alongside performances of performance-music works as part of one single work.

The exhibition will be accompanied by a catalog, which will be a box stuffed with additional works to those presented in the exhibition. We are asking for your support to produce this catalog.

The Catalog

 The catalog is a box that will be filled with different things. Among them new and old images of graphic scores and text scores,  and a recording of three new electronic works on fixed media. It will also include three artistic collaborations with the photographer Ron Amir, as well as the poets Richard Zenith and Zohar Eitan. These collaborations will be presented as  greeting cards, employing  images and texts provided by these artists, upon opening the cards they will play new electronic pieces that are based on materials provided by these artists. In the box there will be a transcription of a talk with the political activist and Philosophy professor Anat Matar discussing secrets. And finally the box will include texts relating to my work by  Dr. Adi Luria (Tel Aviv University), Prof. David Grubbs (Brooklyn College, CUNY, NY),  Noam Ben Zeev (Haaretz), and Liora Belford (curator.) The catalog will be in three languages (English, Hebrew, and Arabic,) and is designed by Harel Schriber who designed my website.

The cost of producing this catalog is prohibitive. It includes  design and translation hours, as well as the cutting and folding of the boxes, the high-quality printing of images, the production of fixed media sounds, and the design and printing of the sound cards with extra memory. The costs of producing these in Israel is higher then most places. If this fundraising campaign will raise more money then is necessary for the production of the catalog we will use the money left over to support the exhibition which is not fully funded yet.



The Exhibition

The exhibition space of the Center will be divided into islands of isolated realms of sounds and images, surrounded by a strictly coordinated bedlam. The score for the composition will serve as an explanatory map for the show; it will be handed to the visitor at the center entrance as a score for a single performer, i.e the visitor. The exhibition will be a performative space of sound and objects, and will exhibit performance works as if they are sound installations. The encounter with these un- announced performances and their performers (such as dancers, musicians), may provide a new subjective experience. The inclusion of live performers as part of an exhibition that lasts three months increases the budget of the exhibition substantially.

The 'Composition for Two Floors and a Corridor' will also include an outdoor sound installation in the museum's garden, sound works for cellular phones, a listening room and a sound work that will transform one floor to a huge 'sound box'. The 'sound box' will be full of sounds but mostly empty of objects. Some of the doors will stay shut, while sound and light coming out of the sealed room will join the composition. Other doors will screech, empowering the visitor as a performer while walking through the 'music box', controlling not only his/her experience of the work, but also the other visitors' experience.

The museum is providing about a fourth of the budget, and the exhibition won support from the highly competitive cultural committee of Mifal Hapais. We are still waiting to hear results from other applications we made.


Thanks for your help

If you read this text all the way to here you already helped the piece. If you would consider contributing that would be great, and if you can let other people know about it. According to the people of Indiegogo it helps if people "make noise" about a campaign so please do, make lots of noise. Thanks

story:
Allow me a triumphant journey.

My name is Jeffrey Collins, I am a painter of over 15 years. I have been based in Columbus Ohio for most of that time. I have recently been broadening my reach to the New York City area. I was blessed to be included in a curated exhibition called Materialists by painter Anders Knutsson, along with fellow painters, Nils Hill and Art Guerra. The exhibition took place in January 2014 at The Painting Center in Chelsea, Manhattan. Along with two entries in the Sideshow Gallery yearly group exhibitions. They have brought knowledge of my work to many in the NY art world.

http://www.jeffreycollins.us

A little over a month ago I was informed of a new Art Residency in Tamaqua Pennsylvania by a friend of mine who lives there. I've visited Tamaqua many times since two colleagues live there and have made the city of Tamaqua their second home. It's a great city for hiking and riding bikes, or just hanging out and enjoying the passage of time. Which is exactly what a painter needs to make great work. I was informed about two weeks later that I was on the shortlist, and a week later was told I would be the first Artist in Residence. I have been so happy about this opportunity since I got that call.

I decided I needed to begin this campaign because I knew I didn't have enough funds to get me through the 3 months of the residency. This is what I am asking your help for. This is my first art residency and I'm so thrilled about it, but I really need your help to get me to the finish line. I've been waiting for something like this to happen for so long and it's finally happening. I just don't want to fall on my face while it is happening.

Your contributions will help me to paint at least ten new paintings, and hopefully a few of them will allow me to really stretch the boundaries of scale in my painting. I have been working on using different materials as my substrates and that material (Acrylic Yarn) is so fun and awesome to use, I'm looking forward to really digging into the ideas it will bring and how I can bring them to life. Your contributions will help to keep me fed, buy art materials and just keep livin.

I sincerely hope with every fiber of my being that you will find this as interesting as I do and be willing and able to contribute to the campaign.


What We Need & What You Get


First and foremost. I need to eat. People who know me know I am not an extravagant foodie. I like sandwiches. And I do need to eat to live. That and oxygen are the two most important aspects of this residency. :-)

I need art supplies. Granted the acrylic yarn does not cost much at all. It's mostly the paint and the chassis materials that will take up a lot of funds.

The first big perk is a self published diary of my trip as an artist in residence in Tamaqua Pennsylvania. I'll be taking many photos while there and keeping a diary of my time. So when you receive it, you'll be able to feel like you were there with me during that time.


The second big perk is definitely something you've probably never heard of before. I refer to them as URN's, they are how I deal with paintings that didn't quite make it. I prefer to always keep all of my work close, giving the painting another life after it has been pulled from the wall.

I have 9 Black Urns from 2013, in singles and 3 in doubles (meaning a painting that was too big to fit into a single Urn canister). The double Urn's will be in their own perk and all will have a brass plate seated on top with the information engraved upon. They are completely sealed and opening them will destroy their value. To allow you to not have to worry about that. I will include a series of printed photographs showing the inside of the Urn before it was sealed, along with a certificate of authenticity.

So far in 2014 I have 1 Urn in Chrome. Each year will utilize a specific color for that year to easily differentiate from one to the other.

^^ The 9 single 2013 Urn's.

^^ The 3 sets of 2013 Urn's.

^^The 2014 Urn.

Just remember you don't have to give the money for the perk to help out. Any contribution is welcomed and sincerely appreciated.

I am asking for $2000 in total as the residency lasts for three months and I hope to be busy all that time. As you might know with a painter...even though they may not have a brush in their hand...doesn't mean they aren't working. I'm a bit frightened about not receiving the full funding as I don't know right now what I'd be up against. But I'm a pretty resourceful person and there seems to be plenty of craftspeople needed around the city. I just don't want to have to be forced to work for my meals during what is supposed to be the most artistic period in my life so far.


    The Impact


    I'm looking forward to meeting with the people of Tamaqua and doing various art projects in their cultural center. Helping Tamaqua to become a place that more artists would want to come to. I'll be doing some helping at the cultural arts center and hopefully will be able to turn some of the local kids onto the wonderfully creative things we do. Maybe I'll get them to screen Gerhard Richter's film, since people seem to like watching him paint. You see this project isn't only important to me, but to the children in the city of Tamaqua too,


    Other Ways You Can Help


    If you are a person who believes in this project, but just don't have the ability, please do help me by getting the word out to others that can help out through email, twitter, facebook, myspace...etc. There are so many ways to help someone these days. This indiegogo platform is just one of many in this age.

    If you are by chance one of the new people in the world of virtual currency, you know about Bitcoin, please come and contribute by scanning the QR code below. Thanks for your virtual help. :-)


    I thank you for your time and patience in reading this.

    Jeffrey Collins: Painter

    You can check out my documentary film company too. And see what I've been accomplishing through film.
    DUOCHROME FILMS

story:
One crew. Ten artists. And a festival for everyone. The Bagage is ready to take over the city of Graz.

    The "B the Beat Festival" is an urban art event unlike any other, combining dance, street shows and film. Artists from all ages and experience levels are invited to share their work and express themselves in the middle of our hometown.

    October 17: street shows and film festival

    October 18: battle and party at the Thalia Bar

    October 18 and 19: workshops with international guests


    What You Give

    By deciding to help us, you take part in making the "B the Beat Festival 2014" a reality. Through the lens of urban dances and street culture, we want to encourage people to speak up and have their voices be heard.

    We have decided to create a platform that allows artists and visitors to relate to urban art expressions in any way they like: be it a freestyle battle, a street show, a film, or simply a party. This is an event unlike any other - and you can make it happen!

    What You Get

    Each one of us has experienced how generous and tightly connected the urban art scene is, connecting people from all over the world into a family-like structure. If you are helping us in making the B the Beat Festival a reality, we want to say Thank You by sharing our unique gifts - and that means all of them, be it a dance or singing class, a painting or even some baked goodness! And not only do you support us - you can also help fellow artists that have create their own T-Shirt and bag prints!!

    And if we don't get there?

    We strongly believe in the power of our community to help us in achieving our goal. However, things happen - maybe we miscalculated somewhere along the way, sponsors don't keep up etc. If we cannot raise the amount to cover our expenses (an amount being quite a bit higher than the sum we are shooting for with this campaign), we will have to let go of our visions, one by one, until a smaller idea that doesn't blow our bank survives.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Terry Campbell, I am a graduate student at CU Boulder. A few years ago I was given the opportunity to create a piece of art after given a piece of gold at a residence art program at Redline. I chose to create a gold hunt. I was not prepared to realize what  it would become.  I want to recreate this gold hunt but on a much larger scale.

I am very interested in creating art outside of the gallery. My goal is to receive $9,000 to buy gold bars for the gold hunt. The lucky individual or group that finds the buried gold gets to keep it. There will be 20 clues that leads you to the buried treasure. All the money raised goes towards purchasing gold bars for the hunt. Even if you don't donate you are still welcomed to participate in the gold hunt. 

Perks can only be used one, but if you donate many times you can get many perks.

More detailed information about this project on the Dal-Forrest Fenn Blog.

http://dalneitzel.com/tag/terry-campbell/

VIDEO PROMOTION COMING SOON.
